It fell that, as I slept,
From out the borderland of sleep,
A radiant vision stept.
A goddess, clad in raiment fair,
With sweet and simple grace;

As for a goddess meet.
A golden cup, within her hand

And this she prest first to her lips,
And then she held to mine.
It was the nectar of the gods,
Surpassing human bliss,
I drank, and felt a joy divine—
Immortal happiness!

To the Editor of the NEWS-LETTER,
DEAR SIR:—
After reading the letter in the last issue of
the NEWS-LETTER, signed '`An Undergraduate," in which the writer decries the idea of
an alumni lacrosse team on the ground that
such a team will eclipse the 'varsity in honor
due it and decrease the interest in the undergraduate team, it occurred to me that I might
perhaps throw a little light upon the matter,
particularly in regard to the Toronto game.
This year, as heretofore, the 'varsity team
has had its full and proper schedule. This
schedule will always remain about as long as
at present, the only change which can be
made from year to year being the substitution
of teams; and this can only be done as new
teams, worthy of our recognition, make their
appearance in lacrosse circles.
The present schedule is without criticism
when all ends are taken into consideration;

that is to say, looked at from the physical condition of the men in order to get a championship team, and the manager's aim to end the
season successfully from a financial standpoint.
It is out of the question for the 'varsity
team to play Toronto, except only in a few
isolated instances, as our season is over before
theirs has fairly commenced. They seldom
take a Southern trip as early as the one last
year, as other big teams, like the Crescents in
New York, prefer, if they play them, to do so
later in the season. Last year, therefore,
was an exception to the rule, and the organization of an alumni team has had nothing to
do with cutting out that game or any other
game, if such had been thought feasible, and
had been possible.
I might add that if we had not been blessed
with a. clear day last year when the Toronto
game was played, that the manager would have
had a sorry account to turn in to the Athletic
Board at the end of the season.
There is little in the writer's contention
that the alumni will be a better team and
accordingly draw the crowds. Such a team,
on the other hand, has the effect of stimulating lacrosse interest in larger circles, and
thus tending to increase the interest of the
public generally, with the corresponding result that all audiences will be larger and more
enthusiastic.
It is also a well recognized fact among all
athletic circles that the best way to get a
championship team in any sport is to have
another good team on which, or with which,
to practice. The alumni have commenced to
fill this position this year, as shown by the
numerous mid-week contests. The results of
such training are already evident, and will be
much more so next year when our undergraduate team will be composed of more
inexperienced men than at present.
Such criticisms as advanced by the writer,
who signs himself 'An Undergraduate,"
show a lack of insight into, not only the
training and practice of a team, but also of
managing and financing a successful series of
games.

1901.
With the year 1901 we come to the fourth
successive season that the University turned
out a highly creditable lacrosse team. Under
Captain Edward Tyler, Jr., we had the
lightest aggregation that ever represented the
"Black and the Blue,"and the attack was often
referred to as Hopkins "flying attack," or
the "mosquito fleet."
The team certainly reached its high-water
mark, although early in the season, at the
time of its Crescent game, which it defeated
on their home grounds in a pouring rain
by the score of 3 to 1. The first time that
the "new moon men" had been beaten by a
college team in eleven years. The explanation of this feat is simply this: That it was a
wet day, Crescents did not have their best team
out, Hopkins was in perfect physical condition
and ran them off their feet, at the same time
playing faultless lacrosse.
Before the Crescent game Hopkins had
beaten All Baltimore, University of Pennsylvania and afterwards the College of the City
of New York. Columbia University fell before our light attack before we met Harvard.
The day for the Harvard game—Monday
before the Swarthmore one—was ideal, and
our manager, Harry Byrne, had been very
diligent in seeing that it was properly advertised, with the result that about fifteen hundred people journeyed out to the then called
American League Park to see the contest.
Harvard's strength was a surprise; they had
a large team on which were several Canadians,
and moreover, not only had they been coached
in the Hopkins style of play, but they also
had Clarence Guggenheimer, who was at
that time attending the Harvaid Law School,
between the posts. Hopkins won out in a
close game by the score of 4 to 0. Most of
the light attack, which averaged only 128
pounds, was so used up that they did not recuperate in time for the Swarthmore game.
The most noticeable playing up to now had
been that of Bertram Bernheini at out home,

To the Editor of the NEWS-LETTER,
DEAR SIR:—
After reading the letter in the last issue of
the NEWS-LETTER, signed '`An Undergraduate," in which the writer decries the idea of
an alumni lacrosse team on the ground that
such a team will eclipse the 'varsity in honor
due it and decrease the interest in the undergraduate team, it occurred to me that I might
perhaps throw a little light upon the matter,
particularly in regard to the Toronto game.
This year, as heretofore, the 'varsity team
has had its full and proper schedule. This
schedule will always remain about as long as
at present, the only change which can be
made from year to year being the substitution
of teams; and this can only be done as new
teams, worthy of our recognition, make their
appearance in lacrosse circles.
The present schedule is without criticism
when all ends are taken into consideration;

that is to say, looked at from the physical condition of the men in order to get a championship team, and the manager's aim to end the
season successfully from a financial standpoint.
It is out of the question for the 'varsity
team to play Toronto, except only in a few
isolated instances, as our season is over before
theirs has fairly commenced. They seldom
take a Southern trip as early as the one last
year, as other big teams, like the Crescents in
New York, prefer, if they play them, to do so
later in the season. Last year, therefore,
was an exception to the rule, and the organization of an alumni team has had nothing to
do with cutting out that game or any other
game, if such had been thought feasible, and
had been possible.
I might add that if we had not been blessed
with a. clear day last year when the Toronto
game was played, that the manager would have
had a sorry account to turn in to the Athletic
Board at the end of the season.
There is little in the writer's contention
that the alumni will be a better team and
accordingly draw the crowds. Such a team,
on the other hand, has the effect of stimulating lacrosse interest in larger circles, and
thus tending to increase the interest of the
public generally, with the corresponding result that all audiences will be larger and more
enthusiastic.
It is also a well recognized fact among all
athletic circles that the best way to get a
championship team in any sport is to have
another good team on which, or with which,
to practice. The alumni have commenced to
fill this position this year, as shown by the
numerous mid-week contests. The results of
such training are already evident, and will be
much more so next year when our undergraduate team will be composed of more
inexperienced men than at present.
Such criticisms as advanced by the writer,
who signs himself 'An Undergraduate,"
show a lack of insight into, not only the
training and practice of a team, but also of
managing and financing a successful series of
games.

1901.
With the year 1901 we come to the fourth
successive season that the University turned
out a highly creditable lacrosse team. Under
Captain Edward Tyler, Jr., we had the
lightest aggregation that ever represented the
"Black and the Blue,"and the attack was often
referred to as Hopkins "flying attack," or
the "mosquito fleet."
The team certainly reached its high-water
mark, although early in the season, at the
time of its Crescent game, which it defeated
on their home grounds in a pouring rain
by the score of 3 to 1. The first time that
the "new moon men" had been beaten by a
college team in eleven years. The explanation of this feat is simply this: That it was a
wet day, Crescents did not have their best team
out, Hopkins was in perfect physical condition
and ran them off their feet, at the same time
playing faultless lacrosse.
Before the Crescent game Hopkins had
beaten All Baltimore, University of Pennsylvania and afterwards the College of the City
of New York. Columbia University fell before our light attack before we met Harvard.
The day for the Harvard game—Monday
before the Swarthmore one—was ideal, and
our manager, Harry Byrne, had been very
diligent in seeing that it was properly advertised, with the result that about fifteen hundred people journeyed out to the then called
American League Park to see the contest.
Harvard's strength was a surprise; they had
a large team on which were several Canadians,
and moreover, not only had they been coached
in the Hopkins style of play, but they also
had Clarence Guggenheimer, who was at
that time attending the Harvaid Law School,
between the posts. Hopkins won out in a
close game by the score of 4 to 0. Most of
the light attack, which averaged only 128
pounds, was so used up that they did not recuperate in time for the Swarthmore game.
The most noticeable playing up to now had
been that of Bertram Bernheini at out home,

and B. Swayne Putts at in home. In this
their first year together they were developing
a team play which made them the following
year the best pair in front of goal that Hopkins
has had to this day. Bernheim was a good,
hard shot, whereas Putts was a wonder at rebounds and placing quick shots when in
close. •

game, when our boys were beaten by superior

"Black and the Blue" had to give up first

college game in four years.
